fields.headline: Wine tasting
fields.bodyText: 1. One man's roasted plum is another's wet cat, startling new research has revealed. 2. According to gainfully employed French scientists, wine tasters base their rapturous descriptions of the bouquet and grape on nothing more than its colour. 3. And to prove it they put an odourless red dye in a glass of white Bordeaux, discovering that the 54 tasters plumped for dark words such as "tar", "tobacco" and "raspberries" to describe it. 4. By rights they should have been getting honeysuckle, with a hint of almond. 5. So will Jilly Goolden be out of a job? Probably not - media wine experts are vastly entertaining (to a section of the population) and they know some mildly useful stuff, such as the best time to uncork a fine vintage. 6. And wine appreciation is, of course, wildly subjective, though a trained taster can spot many different flavours in a single glass of plonk. 7. To try it yourself follow these three steps: look at the colour, savour the smell and then taste it with your tongue, taking account of the texture before you either spit it out or drink it. 8. If you're short of a few pointers try a flavour wheel. 9. Evidence of wine growing dates back 8000 years to ancient Mesopotamia, but it is not known whether its civilisation had developed a sufficient division of labour to support dedicated wine tasters. 10. But even so, wine was possibly used for many of the same reasons it is used today. Enjoying food, oiling conversation and getting drunk - not forgetting that, in moderation, it's good for your health.
